awd_titl_txt: Macromolecular crowding in vitro and in cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Protein-protein interactions regulate all cellular functions, yet they are almost always studied in water rather than in the complex and crowded environment that exists inside cells. The results of this project will fill a key gap that prevents a complete description of metabolism. The goal of moving quantitative biophysics from simple solutions to crowded environments, including inside living cells, is a major challenge with important outcomes. The knowledge gained will add to both the fundamental understanding of biology and inform efforts to produce and stabilize protein-based reagents. The work will also facilitate the training of undergraduate and graduate students in the practice of cutting-edge research. All these efforts are key to building the US bioeconomy.

The overall goal of the project is to gain broadly-applicable knowledge about protein-protein interactions under physiologically-relevant conditions. The focus is on homodimeric interactions in vitro, in Escherichia coli cells and in zebrafish (Danio rerio) oocytes. The overarching hypothesis is that electrostatic interactions between cosolutes and protein complexes dominate the effect of hard-core excluded volume under physiologically-relevant conditions. More specifically, electrostatic attractions between cosolutes and protein complexes are expected to decrease stability of the complexes, whereas electrostatic repulsions are expected to increase stability. The supported research will also deliver to modelers and theoreticians the information required to produce accurate simulations of cellular processes. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Cells sequester all the macromolecules required for life at concentrations that can exceed 300 g/L. Surprisingly, biophysical studies are rarely performed at concentrations exceeding even a few g/L despite results showing that folding intermediates observed in buffer are not necessarily observed in cells, mutations having little effect in buffer alter cellular metabolism and disordered proteins exhibit different ensembles in cells than they do in dilute solution. During this award, we designed experiments, and acquired data to develop, test and publish a new model of macromolecular crowding that incorporates steric exclusion and adsorption. The model does not depend on crowder shape. In the course of these efforts, the PI trained both graduate and undergraduate students in the research laboratory. The data were acquired as a function of crowder size, crowder concentration and temperature by using 19F nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The model explains crowding effects on protein stability in polyethylene glycols and its monomer, ethylene glycol at the level of the free energy, enthalpy and entropy. Steric exclusion dominates for polyethylene glycols of greater than 400 g/mol. Adsorption dominates for ethylene glycol and smaller polyethylene glycols. We hypothesize that the model is general and are testing it using two protein-dimer systems using polyethylene glycol and physiologically-relevant crowders, including a series of designed proteins of increasing size but with similar shapes and surfaces. We also showed that the cellular environment affects the stability of protein-protein interactions and can change the mechanism of protein dimer formation. 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2024
Modified by: Gary J Pielak

Image
  • Our Model is based on exclusion (a) and adsorption (b). Protein, cosolute and solvent are shown in purple, orange and blue, respectively. Surface domain thickness (yellow) is indicated by a, and the relevant surface area of size SASA is depicted in red.
    Stewart, Olgenblum, Harries & Pielak
    Public Domain
    Gary J Pielak
    Our model
